member.name: T:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.DefinitionQueueStatus
member.summary: Specifies the status of a definition queue.

member.name: F:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.DefinitionQueueStatus.Disabled
member.summary: When disabled, the definition queue will not allow for builds to be queued by users and the system will not queue scheduled, gated, or continuous integration builds. Builds already in the queue will not be started by the system.

member.name: F:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.DefinitionQueueStatus.Enabled
member.summary: When enabled, the definition queue allows for builds to be queued by users, the system will queue scheduled, gated, and continuous integration builds, and the queued builds will be started by the system.

member.name: F:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.DefinitionQueueStatus.Paused
member.summary: When paused, the definition queue allows for builds to be queued by users and the system will queue scheduled, gated, and continuous integration builds. Builds in the queue will not be started by the system.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail.Connect
member.summary: Starts polling by using the default interval of five seconds and no synchronization object. When events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, the other overload should be used for this method and that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail.Connect(System.Int32,System.ComponentModel.ISynchronizeInvoke)
member.summary: Starts polling by using the specified interval and ISynchronizeInvoke object. When the StatusChanging, StatusChanged, or PollingCompleted events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.
member.param: The polling interval, in milliseconds.
The object that is used to synchronize polling events. If null, events will be fired on a thread pool thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail.Connect(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.ComponentModel.ISynchronizeInvoke)
member.summary: Starts polling, using the specified interval, time-out and ISynchronizeInvoke object. When the StatusChanging, StatusChanged, or PollingCompleted events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.
member.param: The polling interval, in milliseconds.
The time-out, in milliseconds.
The object that is used to synchronize polling events. If null, events will be fired on a thread pool thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuild.Connect
member.summary: Starts polling, by using the default interval of five seconds and no synchronization object. Events will be fired on a thread pool thread. When events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, the other overload should be used for this method and that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuild.Connect(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.ComponentModel.ISynchronizeInvoke)
member.summary: Starts polling, by using the specified interval and ISynchronizeInvoke object. When the StatusChanged, or PollingCompleted events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.
member.param: The polling interval, in milliseconds.
The time-out, in milliseconds.
The object that is used to synchronize polling events. If null, events will be fired on a thread pool thread.
